Motivation

This tutorial serves as an introduction to a statistical learning tool, called intRo. The goal of intRo is to foster a student interest in coding while learning basic statistics, or at a minimum, help students to learn a bit more about working with data.

As a web-based application, this tool is immediately more familiar to students than a desktop application. The need for dealing with software licenses, installation configuration, and supported platforms has been eliminated. This allows students to spend more time working with the data and learning statistics than having to struggle to get the software running.

There are multiple modules within intRo, which perform specific data analysis tasks that employ an easy to use point-and-click interface. Continue with the tutorial to read more about each one.

Data

The data module allows the user to select or upload a dataset. Several datasets are pre-included, which can be selected via a drop-down menu. The user can check a box to upload a dataset, and then select the text file from their computers (as of 4/9/2014, only CSV files are supported).

Upon selection or successful upload of a dataset, a table view of the data will be visible on the right. There are several features available. First, the user can select the number of records to display per page. Second, the user can click any column of the data in order to sort by that column. Third, search fields are available for both the entire dataset, and each individual column. Finally, the user can page between rows of the dataset with the buttons along the bottom.

The dataset selected in the data module will be made available to all other modules of intRo.

Graphical Summaries

The graphical summaries module provides several common graphical displays of variables in the dataset. First, the user selects between two types of plots, either one variable, or two variables. This choice determines the plot types presented to the user. The user then selects a plot type, and either a single variable, or two variables from the dataset. The plot visible on the right will automatically update when these values are selected. The graphical displays available are:

One Variable
  • Histogram
  • Boxplot
Two Variables
  • Scatterplot
  • Line Chart
  • Boxplot
  • Bar Chart
  • Pareto Chart

Selecting "Bar Chart" or "Pareto Chart" will reveal an additional option. The user can then select the type of the bars. The supported types are the count, sum, mean, and median of the variable selected.

Numeric Summaries

The numeric summaries module is another method of computing summaries of the data. The user is presented with a checkbox list of each variable from their dataset. The user can select one or more different variables, and will be presented with a table of some summary statistics.

The summary statistics displayed vary depending on the type of the variables. For instance, for a numeric variable, a five number summary consisting of the minimum, maximum, first quartile, third quartile, and median will be displayed, along with the mean. Character or factor variables will display counts of each unique value of that particular variable.

Simple Linear Regression

The simple linear regression module allows the user to compute a simple linear regression of a dependent variable (y) on an independent variable (x). The module will automatically filter any variables that are non-numeric so that the user may only select variables that are suitable for a simple linear regression.

Results of the regression will be displayed on the right. A table of parameter estimates, along with standard errors, t statistics, and p-values will be displayed. Beneath it, a scatterplot of the data along with a line of best fit is shown. The R-Squared value, measuring the amount of variability explained by the fit, will be printed in either the top right or bottom right of the plot.
